dialogs.original: Softly and swiftly, sir, for the priest is ready.
dialogs.translated: Quietly and quickly, sir. The priest is ready.

dialogs.original: I fly, Biondello. But they may chance to need thee at home.Therefore leave us.
dialogs.translated: I'm hurrying, Biondello. But they might need you at home, so you go back.

dialogs.original: Nay, faith, Ill see the church a' your back, and then come back to my masters as soon as I can.
dialogs.translated: No, I'll see you safely to the church, and then I'll hurry back to my master's.

dialogs.original: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.
dialogs.translated: I'm surprised Cambio hasn't come by all this time.

dialogs.original: Sir, heres the door. This is Lucentios house.My fathers bears more toward the marketplace.Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.
dialogs.translated: Sir, here's the door. This is Lucentio's house. My father-in-law's house lies closer to the marketplace. That's where I'm off to, and here I leave you, sir.

dialogs.original: You shall not choose but drink before you go.I think I shall command your welcome here,And, by all likelihood, some cheer is toward.
dialogs.translated: You must have a drink before you go. I think I can welcome you on my son's behalf, and it's likely that some entertainment is being prepared anyway.

dialogs.original: Theyre busy within. You were best knock louder.
dialogs.translated: They're busy inside. You'd better knock louder.

dialogs.original: [as VINCENTIO]  Whats he that knocks as he would beat down the gate?
dialogs.translated: [As VINCENTIO] Who's that trying to break down the door?

dialogs.original: Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?
dialogs.translated: Is Sir Lucentio inside, sir?

dialogs.original: [as VINCENTIO]  Hes within, sir, but not to be spoken withal.
dialogs.translated: [As VINCENTIO] He's inside, sir, but he can't be bothered right now.

dialogs.original: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two to make merry withal?
dialogs.translated: What if a man were to bring him a couple hundred pounds to have fun with?

dialogs.original: [as VINCENTIO]  Keep your hundred pounds to yourself. Heshall need none so long as I live.
dialogs.translated: [As VINCENTIO] Keep your hundred pounds to yourself. He won't need anything as long as I'm alive.

dialogs.original: [To VINCENTIO]   Nay, I told you your son was well beloved in Padua.   Do you hear, sir? To leave frivolous circumstances, I pray you tell Signior Lucentio that hisfather is come from Pisa and is here at the door to speak with him.
dialogs.translated: [As VINCENTIO] See, I told you your son was well-loved in Padua.

dialogs.original: [as VINCENTIO]  Thou liest. His father is come from Padua and here looking out at the window.
dialogs.translated: [As VINCENTIO] You are lying. His father has already come to Padua, and here he is looking out the window.

dialogs.original: Art thou his father?
dialogs.translated: Are you his father?

dialogs.original: [as VINCENTIO]  Ay, sir, so his mother says, if I may believe her.
dialogs.translated: [As VINCENTIO] Yes, sir, or so his mother tells me, if I can believe her.

dialogs.original: [To VINCENTIO]  Why, how now, gentleman! Why, this is flat knavery to take upon you another mans name.
dialogs.translated: [To VINCENTIO] Why, what's going on? This is downright criminal, to take on another man's name!

dialogs.original: [as VINCENTIO]  Lay hands on the villain. I believe he means to cozen somebody in this city under my countenance.
dialogs.translated: [As VINCENTIO] Arrest the villain. I believe he means to cheat someone in this city while pretending to be me.

dialogs.original: [aside]  I have seen them in the church together. God send'em good shipping! But who is here? Mine old masterVincentio! Now we are undone and brought to nothing.
dialogs.translated: [To himself] Now I've seen them go into the church together. May God give them a good marriage! But who's this here? My old master Vincentio! Now everything's ruined! It was all for nothing.

dialogs.original: [To BIONDELLO]  Come hither, crack-hemp.
dialogs.translated: [To BIONDELLO] Come here, you villain.

dialogs.original: Hope I may choose, sir.
dialogs.translated: I don't have to obey you, sir.

dialogs.original: Come hither, you rogue! What, have you forgot me?
dialogs.translated: Come here, you rogue! What, have you forgotten me?

dialogs.original: Forgot you! No, sir. I could not forget you, for I never saw you before in all my life.
dialogs.translated: Forgotten you! No, sir. I could not forget you, for I've never seen you before in my life.

dialogs.original: What, you notorious villain, didst thou never see thy masters father, Vincentio?
dialogs.translated: What, you foul villain, did you never see your master's father, Vincentio?

dialogs.original: What, my old worshipful old master? Yes, marry, sir. See where he looks out of the window.
dialogs.translated: What, my respectable old master? Yes, of course, sir. There he is, looking out the window.

dialogs.original: Is t so, indeed.
dialogs.translated: Is that so.

dialogs.original: Help, help, help! Heres a madman will murder me.
dialogs.translated: Help, help, help! There's a madman trying to murder me!

dialogs.original: [as VINCENTIO]  Help, son! Help, Signior Baptista!
dialogs.translated: [As VINCENTIO] Help, son! Help, Sir Baptista!

dialogs.original: Prithee, Kate, lets stand aside and see the end of this controversy.
dialogs.translated: Come on, Kate, let's stand aside and see how all this chaos turns out.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  Sir, what are you that offer to beat my servant?
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Sir, who are you that you would presume to beat my servant?

dialogs.original: What am I, sir! Nay, what are you, sir? O immortal gods! O fine villain!   A silken doublet, a velvet hose, ascarlet cloak, and a copatain hat! Oh, I am undone, I am undone!   While I play the good husband at home, my sonand my servant spend all at the university.
dialogs.translated: Who am I, sir! No, who are you, sir? By the immortal gods! Oh, you complete villain! A silken jacket, velvet hose, a scarlet cloak, and a tall hat! Oh, I'm ruined, I'm ruined! While I played the thrifty father at home, my son and my servant have spent all my money at university.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  How now, whats the matter?
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] What's going on, what's the matter?

dialogs.original: What, is the man lunatic?
dialogs.translated: What, is the man a lunatic?

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]   Sir, you seem a sober ancient gentleman by your habit, but your words show you a madman.   Why, sir, what 'cerns it you if I wear pearl and gold? I thank my good father I am able to maintain it.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Sir, from your clothes you seem to be a wise, respectable old gentleman, but your words show you to be a madman. Why, sir, what is it to you if I should wear pearls and gold? Thanks to my good father, I can afford it.

dialogs.original: Thy father! O villain! He is a sailmaker in Bergamo.
dialogs.translated: Your father! Oh you villain! Your father is a sailmaker in Bergamo.

dialogs.original: You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir. Pray, what do you think is his name?
dialogs.translated: You're mistaken, sir, you're mistaken. Please tell me, what do you think his name is?

dialogs.original: His name! As if I knew not his name! I have brought himup ever since he was three years old, and his name is Tranio.
dialogs.translated: His name! As if I didn't know his name! I raised him ever since he was three years old, and his name is Tranio.

dialogs.original: [as VINCENTIO]  Away, away, mad ass! His name is Lucentio and he is mine only son, and heir to the lands of me, Signior Vincentio.
dialogs.translated: [As VINCENTIO] Away with you, mad fool! His name is Lucentio, my only son, and heir to all the lands owned by me, Vincentio.

dialogs.original: Lucentio! Oh, he hath murdered his master! Lay hold on him, I charge you in the Dukes name. O my son, my son! Tell me, thou villain, where is my son Lucentio?
dialogs.translated: Lucentio! Oh, he's murdered his master! Arrest him, I charge you in the Duke's name. Oh my son, my son! Tell me, you villain, where is my son Lucentio?

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  Call forth an officer.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Call an officer.

dialogs.original: Carry this mad knave to the jail.Father Baptista,I charge you see that he be forthcoming.
dialogs.translated: Take this mad fool to jail.Father Baptista, make sure that he's ready to appear in court when he's called.

dialogs.original: Carry me to the jail?
dialogs.translated: Take me to jail?

dialogs.original: Stay, officer. He shall not go to prison.
dialogs.translated: Wait, officer. He won't go to prison.

dialogs.original: Talk not, Signior Gremio. I say he shall go to prison.
dialogs.translated: Be quiet, Sir Gremio. I say he will go to prison.

dialogs.original: Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be cony-catched in this business. I dare swear this is the right Vincentio.
dialogs.translated: Be careful, Sir Baptista, or else you'll be tricked by this business. I would dare to swear that this is the real Vincentio.

dialogs.original: [as VINCENTIO]  Swear, if thou darest.
dialogs.translated: [As VINCENTIO] Swear, if you dare.

dialogs.original: Nay, I dare not swear it.
dialogs.translated: No, I won't really dare to swear it.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  Then thou wert best say that I am notLucentio.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Then you'd better say that I'm not really Lucentio.

dialogs.original: Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.
dialogs.translated: No, I know you're Sir Lucentio.

dialogs.original: Away with the dotard! To the jail with him!
dialogs.translated: Away with this old fool! Take him to jail!

dialogs.original: Thus strangers may be haled and abused.O monstrous villain!
dialogs.translated: This is how strangers are mistreated and abused!Oh you monstrous villain!

dialogs.original: O! We are spoiled and yonder he is! Deny him, forswear him, or else we are all undone.
dialogs.translated: Oh! There he is, and we're ruined! Deny him, swear that you don't know him, or else we're completely undone.

dialogs.original: Pardon, sweet father.
dialogs.translated: Forgive me, sweet father.

dialogs.original: Lives my sweet son?
dialogs.translated: Is my sweet son alive?

dialogs.original: Pardon, dear father.
dialogs.translated: Forgive me, dear father.

dialogs.original: How hast thou offended? Where is Lucentio?
dialogs.translated: Why, what have you done wrong? Where is Lucentio?

dialogs.original: Heres Lucentio, right son to the right Vincentio,That have by marriage made thy daughter mineWhile counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.
dialogs.translated: Here is Lucentio, the real son of the real Vincentio. I've made your daughter mine by marriage while you were tricked by false appearances.

dialogs.original: Heres packing, with a witness, to deceive us all!
dialogs.translated: A conspiracy, a total conspiracy, that deceived us all!

dialogs.original: Where is that damnèd villain, Tranio,That faced and braved me in this matter so?
dialogs.translated: Where is that damned villain Tranio, who bullied and defied me about this?

dialogs.original: Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?
dialogs.translated: Why, tell me though, isn't this my daughter's tutor Cambio?

dialogs.original: Cambio is changed into Lucentio.
dialogs.translated: Cambio has become Lucentio.

dialogs.original: Love wrought these miracles. Biancas love    Made me exchange my state with Tranio,    While he did bear my countenance in the town,    And happily I have arrivèd at the last    Unto the wishèd haven of my bliss.    What Tranio did, myself enforced him to.    Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.
dialogs.translated: Love performed these miracles. Bianca's love made me trade my identity with Tranio, while he pretended to be me in town. And now at last I've arrived happily at the blissful conclusion of my endeavors. Whatever Tranio did, I commanded him to do. So pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.

dialogs.original: Ill slit the villains nose that would have sent me tothe jail.
dialogs.translated: No, I'll slit the nose of that villain who tried to send me to jail.

dialogs.original: But do you hear, sir, have you married my daughter without asking my goodwill?
dialogs.translated: But is this true, sir, that you've married my daughter without asking for my permission?

dialogs.original: Fear not, Baptista, we will content you. Go to. But I will in to be revenged for this villany.
dialogs.translated: Don't worry, Baptista, we will satisfy you. You'll see. But I will go inside and get some revenge for this villainy.

dialogs.original: And I, to sound the depth of this knavery.
dialogs.translated: And I will too, to see how deep this villainy goes.

dialogs.original: Look not pale, Bianca. Thy father will not frown.
dialogs.translated: Don't look so pale, Bianca. Your father won't be angry with you.

dialogs.original: My cake is dough, but Ill in among the rest,Out of hope of all but my share of the feast.
dialogs.translated: I'm all out of luck, but I'll go in with the rest. The only thing I can hope for now is a share of the feast.

dialogs.original: Husband, lets follow to see the end of this ado.
dialogs.translated: Husband, let's follow them and see how all this turns out.

dialogs.original: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.
dialogs.translated: First kiss me, Kate, and then we will.

dialogs.original: What, in the midst of the street?
dialogs.translated: What, in the middle of the street?

dialogs.original: What, art thou ashamed of me?
dialogs.translated: What, are you ashamed of me?

dialogs.original: No, sir, God forbid, but ashamed to kiss.
dialogs.translated: No sir, God forbid, but I am ashamed to kiss.

dialogs.original: Why, then lets home again.  [To GRUMIO]  Come, sirrah, lets away.
dialogs.translated: Well then, let's go home again.

dialogs.original: Nay, I will give thee a kiss.  [kisses him]  Now pray thee, love, stay.
dialogs.translated: No, I'll give you a kiss.

dialogs.original: Is not this well? Come, my sweet Kate.Better once than never, for never too late.
dialogs.translated: Isn't this nice? Come, my sweet Kate. Better late than never, for never's too late.
